content.rendered:
It is unusually ironic, how the loudest thing to ever exist is silence. The universe dwells in silence, albeit known. But how contradicting it is, as loud as a human can be, the only thing that completes him is silence. Silence never speaks, silence screams; screams in every language known and every language that was to ever exist which is now is dead and long forgotten. Silence is the undisputed although uncrowned King of a deeper reality. It’s amusing to watch men searching for ways to end silence, forging it to be awkward or uncontrolled. But that is the known beauty of silence, it’s uncontrivable, and uncontrollable.

 Humans have become superficial, never searching for a deeper horizon, never seeing past what meets the eye, however silence? Silence challenges men, intimidates them, forcing them to develop perceptions deeper than reality and this…this makes it ‘awkward.’ People, who’ve carved their ways past the superficial levels, people who search for a deeper level of understanding, they have come to admit the beauty of silence. We, although appreciate the deep-rooted silence, we have never been able to see past the leaves of this mammoth tree. Sitting with someone, not sharing the words, but sharing yourself, letting the silence scream, letting the universe mingle with the gluttonous screams of the silence, creating an unparallel symphony of so many words, that is a blessed moment. It is blessed because we have come to realise, it is so rare. Words are abused, anyway.

The silence of the cold winter nights, where the wind howls in the distant; the silence of the good old rainy days, where the only sound that meets your ears is the silence of the raindrops. These moments are when the silence screams the most, demands all of your being. The silence in us, it knows all the answers, it knows all the ways, it just needs to breathe, you need to let it breathe, let the silence communicate.

And Gulzar Sahab has quoted, “Silence is an echo of my voice. There is always an inherent silence in a poem. The poet hides behind that silence and yet he is loud enough to be echoed by those who share his heart beats. My silence is more eloquent than my voice. “

 Have you ever had that ardent desire to be smothered by silence, to let it consume you so gloriously that it rubs the fog right off and makes you see past the fake sonority of the world? If , then take a chance and let yourself inhale the silence, let it speak to you, let it uncover the secrets that you want answers to.

Jaahnavi Pandya

BDS 4th Sem

content.rendered:
“Can I sit here?”-To the person that I asked this to on the first day of my new school, who are you? You introduced yourself to me, I introduced myself to you, I talked to you as I’d talk to anyother stranger, unbeknownst of the great journey ahead of us. Until you were not a stranger anymore, you were someone I respect, someone who’d leave me awestruck with your thoughts on the world and the people within.

I would look down on people, unable to comprehend why people do what they do. I thought you were different, one of a kind that you meet once in a lifetime. You made me realize I was wrong. You were just someone who saw the best in others, in stark contrast to what I did. I metyou, I listened to you and I realized the greatness in people. I remembered everyone I ever met,everyone I looked down upon, and realized how deeply mistaken I was.

To the person who opened my eyes, this is who you are. One among the many that I walked onthe path of life with, the one who moulded me into a better being. Theflow of time will not allow us to walk on the same path forever, but this time we share together will never change.It’s immutable, constant and mine forever. Carved into my mind, impossible to forget.You will be with me-in my thoughts and actions, and the way I live my life. And I’ll be there with you.

All the people I have ever met are still with me. Thousands of fractions of other people’s livesreside within me and a part of me resides within them. It made me who I am. I wonder who they are today.To all the people who led me to this point in time, I am grateful. If we meet again, will we remember the path we shared? Will we go on to create something better? I amcertain we will. To everyone in my past, present and future-let’s meet. I want to create a beautiful path for us to walk upon, so that when we say our last goodbyes, we’d be a better version of ourselves. I want nothing more.

Khadija Sidhpuri

content.rendered:
In the sweaty summers of May, a girl in her bright peachy dress was sauntering in her vineyard and speaking out loud to herself, making notes of what her rest of the day should look like, of thinking about how beautiful the bees look and how confusing quantum physics really is. People were glancing at her awkwardly but she didn’t particularly mind and continued her soliloquy pacing vigorously.

Yep, that girl was me.

My mind and I have the deepest bond, we could just never stop conversing! And sometimes, it comes out loud to make the people around me rather gasp or gawk at me. But that never stops me, or my mind for that matters. Is it just me or does anybody else feel the same way is my biggest question and my mind and I have had huge discussions over this topic a dozen times. There have been occasions where you may be chattering with a person face to face but there is more you like to express which only goes in your mind. It always happens after an argument that I feel I could have counterattacked my opponent by saying something else rather than what I said earlier.

I’ve always found myself pondering over the fact of how amazing our mind functions. The irony that knowing how a mind functions itself needs a mind is mind-blowing. To deepen my knowledge about the phenomenon of talking to oneself, I found some intriguing inferences online. It said in an article that inner speech isn’t bound by the conventions of verbal speech and due to this very fact inner speech cites an average of 4000 words per minute which is ten times faster than verbal and thus obviously more condensed because we don’t need to use full sentences to talk to ourselves, because well we know what we mean without the use of proper grammar and punctuations.

Everyone loves having little time to themselves in a day doing nothing and lazing around. But your mind never leaves you. You could be doing something as mundane as looking for the right keys from the jumbled ones in your hands on a hectic Monday morning or could be potentially working your ass off for a pivotal event; at any given such time, the urge to talk to yourself could happen. Hence, everyone has the habit of talking to themselves. No one can deny it.

I get my idea to write, to play music unknowingly through my gossiping with my mind. An ‘ad nauseam behavior’, my baby sister would mock me, but don’t we all love our little unknown chit-chats with our wandering minds?

Gautam Gandhi

EC 7th Sem

Vrushali Ranadive

content.rendered:
In India, marriage is a very auspicious occasion. There are festive occasions in India, and in most cases celebrated with extensive decorations, color, music, dance, costumes, and rituals that depend on the community, region, and religion of the bride and the groom, as well as their preferences. India celebrates about 10 million weddings per year, of which about 80% are Hindu weddings.

I guess most of us are curious about the rituals and why they are performed. I was also curious to know more about these rituals and thus asked my grandparents. They explained a lot to me. Everyone knows that the darker the bride’s mehndi, the stronger her marriage will be! Another belief is that if the Mehendi lasts longer in the hands of the bride than her fiancé, she’ll be loved a lot by her in-laws! Weird, right? So the actual reason why mehndi is applied is that it calms the nerves and keeps the body from becoming tense. Plus you will be surprised to know that Mehendi is a highly antiseptic agent which can protect you from viral diseases. Our ancestors were very superior in terms of science and religion. Every ritual introduced by them is based on a scientific reasons. I was also surprised when I heard about the vermillion. Apart from being the symbol of matrimony for a Hindu woman, sindoor (red vermilion powder) has some great health benefits as well. It contains turmeric, lime, and a minute level of the metal mercury. So, when it’s applied to the hair partition, the mercury cools down the body and makes you feel relaxed.

Most of the rituals have some reasons whereas some of them are superstitious. I couldn’t stop laughing when I heard about the wedding outfits. The reason couples are always discouraged from lending their wedding dress to someone is that it may bring the borrower good luck, but this generosity can bring bad omen to lenders. So, if you are thinking about lending your wedding dress to someone else then I say think again.

Weddings are one of those rare occasions when Indian parents let their kids loose and are not that strict. That’s the most fun part. Who needs an orchestra? When it comes to Indian weddings, it’s the aunties with their dholaks and chamchas all the way! Not to forget the impromptu ‘rishta’ pairings. Uncles and aunties are always hunting for suitable grooms or brides for their single kids.

In a lot of traditions, the bride’s mother playfully catches the groom’s nose – this is to remind him to always treat her daughter well. A similar ceremony exists in Marathi weddings called ‘kaanapalli’, where the bride’s brother playfully twists the groom’s ear to extract a similar promise from the groom. Funny, isn’t it?

There are weddings and then there are Indian weddings, and it makes a hell of a lot of a difference when you get to be a part of them. Indian wedding is an endless food fare. I enjoy being a guest in wedding because of the exotic cuisine arranged by the families of bride and groom. There is no denying, Indians love to eat and prepare some fancy and flavorsome dishes. Of course, the wedding time when the hosts prepare the best dishes of the region along with the popular dishes in India to treat their guests with an unsurpassed gastronomic experience. This is the reason why I love to attend the wedding!

Gautam Gandhi

IT 4th Sem

Gaurav Jha

<p><span lang="EN-US">Goodbye! It is such a self-contradictory
word. How is bidding farewell to something or someone even good? Or is it? Why
do we need to say goodbye to the things we are most attached to? For instance,
childhood. Everyone’s favorite phase of life, filled with so much rejoice and
excitement and cute innocence. But then puberty hits, and it might have hit
hard to a few of us, leaving us no choice except to say goodbye. A humongous
list pops out in my mind whenever I think of things that have been an integral
part of my life but had to bid goodbye even for a moment or two if not forever.
Like those crazy, full-of-life days with school friends, insane bike rides in
the town, chess and badminton games with papa, our old house which turned into
a home then, and a very recent one – our hostels and colleges. How can I forget
how much I miss the fights with my sibling too? Oh no, okay, I still do that –
the only constant encountered so far. Just kidding! </span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US">Do you remember a time
when you had to say goodbye to someone who has been your ride-or-die person,
your come-hell-or-high water person, your lobster, be it your best friend,
cousin, family member, significant other, or anyone? Goodbyes are goddamn hard
at that point, right? It sounds dreadful that someone who mattered to you more
than your life is no longer with you, either for some time or maybe forever.
Please, don’t kill me for saying this, but what if I say we should be grateful
for this? For what? For having someone with whom you cherished lifelong
memories which will always blossom in your heart. For finding your forever. A
few people have the privilege of meeting their forever type of person, and if
we are one of them, we should be grateful for that. We are so lucky if we have
met someone who makes goodbyes the hardest. If that is something we are not
grateful for, I don’t know for what else we would be? We cannot keep all the
gifts of life. </span><span lang="EN-US">Some things<span style="color:black"> we
are just lent. This reminds me of lines, <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Muskuraye
toh Muskurane ke karz utaarne honge</i>. The brutal truth is we are the only
guaranteed forever in our life.<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US"><span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span></span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US">You must be pondering then why the word
includes “good” in it? Sometimes goodbyes can be the gateway to growth. A
courageous leap into the new beginning. There will always be something lying in
front of us that will be much more than what we’ve lost – a person, a memory,
or that lingering bad habit. If we’ll keep re-reading that old chapter – being
the same old us, never trying to upgrade, how will we be able to move to the
next better chapter – better us? So, let us all say goodbye to the normal and
hello to the extraordinary. I guess debate on this word will be never-ending. I
will always have a love-hate relationship with this word. What are your
views?<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></p></div>

Nothing ever dies an ultimate death in middle-class families. Probably the toothpaste hack is the most famous one wherein toothpaste is dissected and used until the inner surface shines vibrantly. Indian mothers are known for recycling things. You never know that the Holi colors once you used could be used again on Diwali. Every single thing is saved from being disposed of by saying “It might be helpful soon”.

Once upon a time disciple of Buddha asked for a new robe. Buddha questioned that what you did with the old robe. Disciple answered, “I made a curtain out of it”.  What about the old curtain? Buddha asked. “Oh, that I converted into a bedsheet”. And the old bed sheet? “I made mop out of it”. And the mop? “Dear Lord mops was in the stranded form so I made wicks out of it and I light it up every evening”. Buddha smiled upon the enlightenment of his disciple. That disciple is none other than an Indian Mother. When kanjoosi went abroad for studying it returned as sustainability. What was considered cheap then is now cool! Recycling is seen everywhere and at every step. The newspaper becomes book covers and glossy magazines are turned into a cone for eating mouth-watering bhel. If jeans were torn off then they get a makeover as shorts. However, now Ripped jeans are a style statement.

Every middle-class kid would have felt embarrassed because of the thrifty ways of their mom. It’s just that after we started using phones we came to know that those DIY videos were inspired by our household’s methods. Being frugal is considered cool but without economic restrictions. They might have been raised under tough economic situations so they value money and things bought. Throwing away things is just not their cup of tea. “It cannot be thrown so it must be reused!” It’s their perfect ideology for sustainability.

Try entering the kitchen and their mindful hacks will blow your mind! Leftover rice gets refurbished into mouthwatering cutlets. Pav bhaji was originally a mesh of leftover veggies. This art of recycling and reusing is every environmentalist’s dream. Save- the-planet folks must appoint Indian Mom as president. It’s no longer being a miser but it’s all about being #woken_up.

You are an extraordinary assortment of skills that left me amused when I first saw your interviews. I would rather say that are beyond amazing. You are an engineering teacher, Kannada, Marathi, and English author as well as a social worker. I wonder how could you manage to serve so many rules despite so many responsibilities. Maybe you are superhuman!

Your story always inspired me and kept me motivated. I would like to read your books How I taught my Grandmother to Read, Wise and Otherwise, and three thousand stitches! The description of The three thousand stitches left me with a great impact.

You have always been a star student from your childhood until you completed your graduation! I remember one of the stories of your post-graduation from the Indian Institute of Science Bangalore. The principal asked you to wear a saree as well as he demanded from you that you should not talk with any boy in the college premises. Of course, you fulfilled the demands but after achieving first place among six hundred students, the classmates started approaching you, and you had become the center of attention. I must say you have turned the tables very well.

You became the first female engineer hired as India’s largest auto manufacturer TATA Engineering and Locomotive Company (TELCO). I appreciate your courage about writing a postcard to the company’s chairman complaining about the “man only” gender bias at TELCO. As a result, you were granted a special interview and because of your skills, you were hired immediately. I cannot count how many awards and appreciation you have earned! You even won India’s fourth highest civilian award Padma Shri.

Here is the reason why I have chosen to write you a letter. Murthy is one of the trustees of the Infosys Foundation which was founded in 1996. Through Foundation you built 2300 houses in flood-affected areas! Your great vision of the library for each school has resulted in the setting up of 70,000 libraries so far. I remember that when you appeared as a guest on KBC you highlighted the importance of toilets as the college in which you studied didn’t have any woman admitted before at that time. So you built 16000 public toilets and several hundreds of toilets in the city of Bangalore.

You are an amazing person who easily switches roles from storytelling to social service and administration. In one of your interviews, I read about how you miss being a teacher. I think how lucky must the students be who were your students back then. I wish if I could ever attend your speech. The only thought of it makes me so cheerful!

“Life is an exam where the syllabus is unknown and question papers are not set. Nor are there model answer papers.” Your quote inspired me a lot. It explained to me as well as the others the true meaning of life. Meeting you in person will be a wish in my bucket list!

Muskan Vora

content.rendered:
Communication is one of the key aspects of any human being’s life. The art of communication is one of the key factors that separates us from animals and its development has greatly influenced the development of cultures and traditions in various parts of the world. Communication has evolved greatly over the years, especially long-distance communication which has taken strides from riding on the back of a pigeon to riding on huge networks of data. But the most important element long-distance communication lacks is the proper display of emotions, that is understanding the message by the person’s expressions rather than his words. However, this problem has been solved to a great extent by the use of emoticons, gifs and stickers.

Emoticons or emojis are tiny pixelated faces that we use to add emotion to our message. Whether it is love wrapped in anger or a joke wrapped in sarcasm emoticons never fail to add colour to the conversation. A grin after a sarcastic comment, a heart from a loved one, laughter after a funny comment or anger after a fight all these emotions which were once impossible to show in a text message are now just a tap away. They have become such an important part of our conversation that the tone of our message is not defined by its words but rather by the emoticons that follow.

Another form of messaging that has reached the peak of the trending bar nowadays is the use of gifs and stickers. Originally introduced during the advent of the art form of meme-making, these famous dialogues have now become a part of every tiny conversation and do not fail in turning the greatest fights to the greatest smiles. Be it a famous dialogue from Hera Pheri, a sarcastic comment by Jethalal or post-match cries of a humorous cricket fan, all of them have been converted into tiny bits of data and have now become the morning tea of our conversations. In fact, their use has increased so much that special keyboards have been designed each with their unique range of gifs and stickers. Their eminent usage has also led to the birth of memers in every part of the town. They might consume a bit more data than the usual text but they surely save us the trouble of making a dull conversation interesting.

Very often, a few emoticons at the end of the message can help preventing future misunderstandings. For example, a laughing face is often added after a sarcastic reply to make sure it is interpreted in the right way. However, they don’t always represent the actual mood of the sender. For instance, a punch emoji doesn’t necessarily mean you would hit the person or an angry face doesn’t always represent anger. They are just used figuratively to spice up the conversation and add more life to it. In fact, anger emoji is hardly ever used to show anger. Sometimes emoticons are sent just to make the receiver happy.

For instance, we often add a pile of laughing emojis after a joke without even grinning at it, just to keep the conversation going. Emoticons and stickers can add colors to the conversation but true colors of a person can only be seen by meeting them for real and sharing our laughs with a real smile than a virtual one.

Mufaddal Suratwala

IT 3rd Sem
